text:
National Rosé Day is an annual designation observed on the second Saturday in June.

Rosé is probably the oldest known type of wine, dating back as far as 600 BC. Rosé is generally made from red grapes. The pink color vary depends on the time the grape skin stays in contact with the juice, also known as maceration. The pink color can range from very light pale pink to almost an red color depends on the grapes and winemaking techniques. There are rosés that are still, semi-sparkling or sparkling with different intense of sweetness levels and dryness. Rosé wines are made from a wide variety of grapes and are a very versatile wine that complement many types of food. Rosé is lighter than a red wine and deeper than the whites. Rosé is simply the perfect wine.

Rosé wines are made from a wide variety of grapes and are a very versatile wine that complement many types of food.

National Rosé Day was submitted to and approved by the registrar of National Day Calendar in October of 2014 by Bodvár of Sweden – House of Rosés – a rosé house specializing in rosé wines to raise awareness and give rosé lovers a day to celebrate with “summer’s water”.

Media Contact:

Ann Hafström

Brand Manager | Head of Social Media | Coordinator

Bodvár of Sweden
